fields.value: EI Extended Model and the Fear of Ecological Fallacy, Sociological Methods & Research, Aug 2007; vol. 36: pp. 3 - 25.

dsDescriptionValue.value: The growth of literature using EI method has not led to a consensus on the effectiveness of EI as a solution to the ecological inference problem. The most critical scrutiny of EI came from those scholars who directly questioned the model assumptions of EI and the consequences of violations of these assumptions. More recently, the EI’s extended model, rather than its basic model, has been suggested as the best hope to save EI from the trouble of violations of model assumptions, especially logical inconsistency. This paper takes advantage of a unique opportunity to compare the controversial methods, including survey approach, by using aggregate as well as individual level data from an actual election. Furthermore, the true quantities of interest are also available, which guarantees the accuracy of the empirical tests. Our results show that EI basic model provided a better estimate for the black turnout rate, but not for the white turnout, than did the traditional Goodman and double regression methods. However, using an appropriate covariate in the EI extended model can drastically improve the estimation accuracy.

keywordValue.value: ecological inference, EI extended model, ecological fallacy

files.description: Comment on “EI extended model and the fear of ecological fallacy”, by Baodong Liu by Jeffrey S. Zax, University of Colorado at Boulder.  Abstract: The results in Liu (2007) are suspect. He claims to validate double regression, but his results validate the critique of this technique. Moreover, he misrepresents the properties of all of his estimators. Lastly, he demonstrates that aggregation bias is present, but uses techniques which do not correct for that bias.  Keywords: Ecological regression, Double regression
files.label: MS-149.pdf
